questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) QALY

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the image of chromosome 15 represented here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or by maternal uniparental disomy, and is characterized by obesity due to hyperphagia, intellectual disability, and specific behavioral traits.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a diagnostic test for CML? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) FISH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). This test detects the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is the result of a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, creating the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene produces a protein with abnormal tyrosine kinase activity, which drives the pathogenesis of CML.
  • • Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Bone marrow Aspiration : While it can show increased cellularity and myeloid hyperplasia, i.e. help in assessing the extent of disease and marrow involvement but is not definitive for diagnosing CML.
  • • Option B. Bone marrow Aspiration
  • • Option C. LAP score : Low in CML but also low in other conditions, hence not specific.
  • • Option C. LAP score
  • • Option D. Karyotyping : While it can detect chromosomal abnormalities, it is less sensitive compared to FISH for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene.
  • • Option D. Karyotyping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard diagnostic test for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) because it specifically identifies the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: An unconscious patient in ICU is on endotracheal intubation and now needs a tracheostomy. What type of tube should be considered in this situation? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cuffed tracheostomy tube

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cuffed tracheostomy tube : This type of tube is preferred for patients who require prolonged mechanical ventilation. The cuff can be inflated to:
  • • Cuffed tracheostomy tube
  • • Prevent Aspiration : The cuff acts as a barrier, preventing secretions from the upper airway from entering the trachea and lungs. Maintain Positive Pressure Ventilation : The cuff ensures that air does not leak around the tracheostomy tube, which is crucial for effective mechanical ventilation.
  • • Prevent Aspiration : The cuff acts as a barrier, preventing secretions from the upper airway from entering the trachea and lungs.
  • • Prevent Aspiration
  • • Maintain Positive Pressure Ventilation : The cuff ensures that air does not leak around the tracheostomy tube, which is crucial for effective mechanical ventilation.
  • • Maintain Positive Pressure Ventilation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Uncuffed tracheostomy tube : Not suitable for patients who are at risk of aspiration or who require positive pressure ventilation since it does not provide a seal.
  • • Option A. Uncuffed tracheostomy tube
  • • Option C. Metallic tracheostomy tube : Typically used in long-term tracheostomies but lacks a cuff, which means it cannot prevent aspiration or maintain a seal for positive pressure ventilation.
  • • Option C. Metallic tracheostomy tube
  • • Option D. Endotracheal tube : This is used for short-term airway management and is not suitable for long-term tracheostomy requirements.
  • • Option D. Endotracheal tube

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For unconscious patients in ICU requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation, a cuffed tracheostomy tube is the preferred choice. The cuff provides a seal to prevent aspiration and ensure effective positive pressure ventilation, making it safer and more effective for such patients.

questions.text: Crohn’s disease in comparison to ulcerative colitis is least likely to show which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: B. Continuous involvement of the gut
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Continuous involvement of the gut is least likely to be associated with Crohn's disease, which is characterized by segmental, patchy inflammation known as "skip lesions."

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 11

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is calculated based on eye response, verbal response, and motor response, with a total score indicating the level of consciousness.

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair(s) of pharyngeal arch and its artery? 1st arch - Maxillary artery 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery 4th arch - Subclavian artery 6th arch - Aorta on the left side
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • All the given pairs of pharyngeal arteries and their arteries are correctly matched except for 'v' (option C).
  • • The 6th pharyngeal arch has its blood supply on the left side from the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus, not from the aorta.
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • 1st arch - Maxillary artery : Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery : Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery. 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.
  • • 1st arch - Maxillary artery : Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch.
  • • 1st arch - Maxillary artery
  • • 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch.
  • • 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery:
  • • 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery : Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery.
  • • 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery
  • • 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.
  • • 4th arch - Subclavian artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: For newborn hearing screening purpose, which test is most commonly used? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) OAE

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Azathioprine is not a first-line drug for the management of rheumatoid arthritis; the primary first-line drugs are sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.
  • ➤ Note -
  • ➤ Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine are considered safe for use during pregnancy and are preferred in the management of RA among pregnant patients. Azathioprine is also somewhat safe during pregnancy, but it is not as effective for RA, so it is less preferred compared to Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine. Methotrexate and Leflunomide are not safe for use during pregnancy and should be avoided due to potential risks to the developing fetus.
  • ➤ Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine are considered safe for use during pregnancy and are preferred in the management of RA among pregnant patients.
  • ➤ Sulfasalazine
  • ➤ Hydroxychloroquine
  • ➤ Azathioprine is also somewhat safe during pregnancy, but it is not as effective for RA, so it is less preferred compared to Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine.
  • ➤ Azathioprine
  • ➤ Methotrexate and Leflunomide are not safe for use during pregnancy and should be avoided due to potential risks to the developing fetus.
  • ➤ Methotrexate
  • ➤ Leflunomide
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis management: Range of biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (bDMARDs) and targeted synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (tsDMARDs).

questions.text: A lady with mitral stenosis who is bedridden, develops sudden onset shortness of breath. On examination, she has a swollen red limb with pain in the calf. What is the clinical diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient, who is bedridden with mitral stenosis, presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb with calf pain. These clinical features strongly suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The sudden shortness of breath indicates that a thrombus from the DVT has likely embolized to the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism. This is a common and potentially life-threatening complication in bedridden patients.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pulmonary edema: This is characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, typically secondary to heart failure, and does not present with a swollen, red limb or calf pain.
  • • Option B. Pulmonary edema:
  • • Option C. Cerebral embolism: This would present with neurological deficits, not shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb.
  • • Option C. Cerebral embolism:
  • • Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus passes from the venous to the arterial system through a cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale). While this could be considered if there were signs of arterial embolism, the presentation here is more consistent with pulmonary embolism.
  • • Option D. Paradoxical embolism:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in bedridden patients presenting with sudden onset shortness of breath and clinical signs of deep vein thrombosis, such as a swollen, red, painful limb.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with cola colored urine and had a history of skin infection few days back. His creatinine value was initially 2.5 mg/dl but even after 3 weeks of treatment it increased to 4.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is a likely kidney biopsy finding on electron microscopy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Crescents in glomeruli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of crescents in the glomeruli on kidney biopsy is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), especially in a patient with worsening renal function following an episode of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

  • ➤ Function: Vitamin A plays a vital role in the growth and development of human cells, controlling the immune system by preventing infections, and activating white blood cells
  • ➤ Function:
  • ➤ Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, poor immune function, and impaired growth and development.
  • ➤ Deficiency Symptoms:

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.
  • • Among the three early markers of myocardial injury , three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.
  • • three early markers of myocardial injury
  • • myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.
  • • Option A. Troponin:
  • • Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.
  • • Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase):
  • • Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.
  • • Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

questions.text: Match the characteristics resulting from the compression of the listed structures in the event of thyroid enlargement. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea. Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing. Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome : Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.
  • • Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea.
  • • Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing):
  • • Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing.
  • • Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing):
  • • Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome : Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms.
  • • Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome
  • • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.
  • • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about a patient with G6PD deficiency? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Males and females can be affected

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency increases oxidative stress in red blood cells, leading to hemolysis and formation of Heinz bodies. It affects both males and females, though more commonly males.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CD21

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

questions.text: A 27y primigravida has just delivered. When removing the placenta, uterine inversion is noted. What is the next immediate step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

questions.correct_answer: C. Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Uterine inversion is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when the uterus turns inside out after delivery. Immediate management is crucial to prevent severe hemorrhage and shock. The next immediate step in the management of uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached. This is done to quickly restore the uterus to its normal position and reduce the risk of continued bleeding and shock.
  • • After manually repositioning the uterus, the healthcare provider should maintain the position by keeping a fist inside the uterus and administering uterotonic agents such as oxytocin to promote uterine contractions, which help to keep the uterus in place and reduce bleeding. The placenta should only be removed after the uterus has been repositioned successfully.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Shift to OT immediately: While surgical intervention may be required if manual repositioning fails, the initial step is to manually reposition the uterus.
  • • Option A. Shift to OT immediately:
  • • Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to increased bleeding and is not recommended.
  • • Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus:
  • • Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver: This maneuver involves using fluid pressure to reposition the uterus and is used if manual repositioning fails. It is not the immediate next step.
  • • Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immediate step in managing uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached, followed by administration of uterotonic agents to maintain the uterus in its correct position.

questions.text: A child is presenting with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash and spots in the oral cavity as shown in the given image, what is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)

questions.correct_answer: C. Cervical branch of facial nerve
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 10 year old girl post tonsillectomy ate a packet of chips 2-3 days after the surgery and now came to the hospital with oral bleed. What shall be the management?

options.label: C
options.text: Conservative management with observation and ice chips.

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate cauterization of the bleeding site

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antibiotics with semisolid food

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-tonsillectomy bleeding is a potential complication that can be managed conservatively with antibiotics and dietary modifications, such as semisolid food, to prevent further mechanical trauma to the surgical site. However, the approach to management should be tailored to the severity of the bleeding and the clinical condition of the patient, with more aggressive interventions like surgical exploration or cauterization reserved for significant or persistent bleeding.

questions.text: During evaluation of PUO, a patient's chest X-ray is as seen below. What is your diagnosis?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Miliary tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given chest X-ray depicts miliary tuberculosis.
  • • Miliary tuberculosis:
  • • Miliary tuberculosis:
  • • Bilateral randomly distributed nodules on HRCT. Hematogenous spread.
  • • Bilateral randomly distributed nodules on HRCT.
  • • Hematogenous spread.
  • • Miliary pattern D/D:
  • • Miliary pattern D/D:
  • • Healed varicella TPE/ Loeffler’s syndrome Hemosiderosis Silicosis
  • • Healed varicella
  • • TPE/ Loeffler’s syndrome
  • • Hemosiderosis
  • • Silicosis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pulmonary edema: Typically presents with bilateral opacities, predominantly in the perihilar regions, and may show Kerley B lines, none of which are visible in this X-ray.
  • • Option B. Pulmonary edema:
  • • Option C. Necrobiotic nodules: Commonly associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, presenting as larger, well-defined nodules, which is not the case here.
  • • Option C. Necrobiotic nodules:
  • • Option D. Tuberculoma: Typically appears as a solitary, well-defined round lesion, often with a calcified center, not the diffuse pattern observed here.
  • • Option D. Tuberculoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Miliary tuberculosis is characterized by fine, diffuse nodules throughout the lungs, resulting from widespread dissemination of the tuberculosis bacteria. This is a serious condition requiring immediate medical attention and treatment.
  • ➤ Miliary tuberculosis is characterized by fine, diffuse nodules throughout the lungs, resulting from widespread dissemination of the tuberculosis bacteria. This is a serious condition requiring immediate medical attention and treatment.

questions.text: A patient had an RTA that caused crush injury. Within 3 days of the injury and post-amputation, crepitus was present and the wound was reddish brown. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gas gangrene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gas gangrene, characterized by rapid tissue destruction, gas production, and a reddish-brown appearance of the wound, should be promptly recognized and managed due to its potential for rapid progression and systemic complications.

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid molecules that play a crucial role in various physiological processes in the body. They are formed from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid has (20 C, 4=) and is synthesized from linoleic acid. Eicosanoids (Prostaglandins and leukotrienes) are synthesized from arachidonic acid. So, Linoleic acid is considered as most essential fatty acid.
  • ➤ Extra Information on PUFAs
  • ➤ Extra Information on PUFAs

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 224

questions.text: In which urinary components is Tamm Horsfall protein present? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) urine cast

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tamm-Horsfall protein (uromodulin) is present in urine casts and is the most abundant protein found in normal human urine.

questions.text: Which of the following feature is correct on the basis of given karyotype? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is characterized by gynecomastia, long limbs, small testes, and infertility.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 316-317
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 316-317

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the ER with a two-day history of worsening ear pain and drainage. He was evaluated in the clinic 5 days ago and diagnosed with acute right otitis media. He was placed on amoxicillin and he initially appeared to improve until two days ago when his ear pain recurred and this is now accompanied by ear drainage, redness behind his right ear, and a prominent right pinna which is pointing down and out as shown below. The most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Mastoiditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media, can present with post-auricular redness, abscess, and displacement of the pinna, requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anti-CMV IgG antibodies? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes

options.label: D
options.text: IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

questions.correct_answer: D. IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection
questions.explanation: Ans. D) IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection
